notes.title: First Isomorphism Theorem (Groups) & Normal Subgroups
notes.content: State and use: for a homomorphism φ: G → H, G/ker φ ≅ im φ. Typical CSS asks: prove kernel is normal; compute factor groups; use to classify structures.
keyTakeaways: Kernel ⊲ G; quotient by kernel maps isomorphically to image.
Useful to show nontrivial homomorphic images and factor groups in exam proofs.
Combine with index arguments (Lagrange) and with centers/normalizers.

resources.title: Wolfram MathWorld — First Group Isomorphism Theorem
Math3ma — The First Isomorphism Theorem, Intuitively
FPSC CSS Syllabus — Pure Mathematics (Modern Algebra topics)

notes.title: Groups of Prime Order; Criterion via G/Z(G)
notes.content: Standard results recur: every group of prime order is cyclic; if G/Z(G) is cyclic then G is abelian; exam proofs often mix centers, normalizers, and factor groups.
keyTakeaways: Use Lagrange to show orders of elements divide |G|.
Center arguments turn group into abelian via cyclic quotient.
Expect short proofs; practice writing crisp arguments.

resources.title: CSS Syllabus (Modern Algebra bullets on centers, inner automorphisms)
MIT OCW 18.06 notes (group analogies appear with linear maps)

notes.title: Finite Integral Domain ⇒ Field (Ring Theory staple)
notes.content: CSS repeatedly asks to prove a finite integral domain is a field. Key idea: nonzero elements have multiplicative inverses (injective ⇒ surjective over finite sets).
keyTakeaways: Use cancellation and finiteness to prove bijectivity of multiplication map.
Alternative: every finite ring element is unit or zero-divisor.
Apply to ℤₙ: field iff n is prime.

resources.title: Math StackExchange — Finite integral domain is a field (standard proof)

notes.title: Ideals, Maximal Ideals & Factor Rings
notes.content: Show kernels are ideals; identify maximal ideals and use R/M is field ⇔ M maximal; compute ideals in ℤ, ℤₙ, and M₂(ℝ) counterexamples.
keyTakeaways: Maximal ideals correspond to fields in quotient.
Principal ideals in PID examples are exam favorites.
Know quick tests for units/zero divisors in ℤₙ.

notes.title: Rank–Nullity Theorem & Subspace Calculus
notes.content: Compute rank, nullity; identify column space/ker; common tasks: basis, dimension, independence, subspace tests.
keyTakeaways: dim(ker A)+dim(im A)=n; row ops preserve rank.
Pivot columns → basis for column space; free vars → basis for null space.
Expect problems mixing systems (existence/uniqueness) with rank.

resources.title: 3Blue1Brown — Inverse matrices, column space & null space (video)

notes.title: Eigenvalues, Diagonalization & Jordan Form (+ Cayley–Hamilton)
notes.content: Common patterns: compute eigenvalues/eigenvectors; check diagonalizability; use Cayley–Hamilton to find A⁻¹ or powers; brief exposure to Jordan form.
keyTakeaways: Diagonalizable iff geometric multiplicities sum to n.
Cayley–Hamilton: every matrix satisfies its characteristic polynomial.
Jordan form organizes non-diagonalizable cases.

notes.title: ε–δ Limits, Continuity & MVT (Real Analysis)
notes.content: Define limit/continuity rigorously; show differentiability ⇒ continuity; state Mean Value Theorem & typical inequality applications; construct counterexamples (|x| at 0).
keyTakeaways: Be fluent with ε–δ proofs on polynomials/rational functions.
Use MVT to prove bounds and uniqueness.
Continuous but non-differentiable at points: exam classic.

resources.title: Paul's Online Math Notes — Calculus I/II/III hubs

notes.title: Riemann Sums, Definite Integrals & Area/Volume
notes.content: Set up Riemann sums; convert to integrals; common tasks: area between curves, volumes of revolution, line/double integrals in simple regions.
keyTakeaways: Partition → sum → limit formalism.
Use symmetry & substitutions in exam-time constraints.
Sketch region carefully before double integrals.

resources.title: Khan Academy — Unit on Riemann sums

notes.title: Sequences, Series & Tests of Convergence
notes.content: Alternating/absolute convergence; ratio/root tests; power series radius/interval; expand standard functions.
keyTakeaways: Know quick test selection (p-series, comparison, ratio/root).
Endpoints often need separate checks for power series.
Maclaurin series expansions are time-savers.

notes.title: Cauchy–Riemann Equations & Analyticity
notes.content: Check analyticity of f(z)=u+iv via CR equations; convert to polar versions; typical exam asks: show harmonicity, find harmonic conjugate.
keyTakeaways: CR with continuous partials ⇒ analytic (holomorphic).
u, v harmonic; can reconstruct conjugate via line integrals.
Know polar CR forms for practice problems.

notes.title: Cauchy's Integral Theorem & Formula
notes.content: State theorem on simply connected domains; path independence; integral formula for derivatives; basic contour integrals.
keyTakeaways: Integral over closed curve of holomorphic function is zero (simply connected).
Cauchy integral formula yields values & derivatives via contour integrals.
Builds foundation for residue methods.

notes.title: Residue Theorem & Real-Integral Applications
notes.content: Compute residues at simple/higher-order poles; evaluate real integrals via contour integration; common CSS tasks include unit-circle rational integrals.
keyTakeaways: Residue at simple pole: lim (z−z0)f(z).
Choose contours wisely (Jordan's lemma style for exponentials).
Identify removable vs pole vs essential singularities first.

notes.title: Fourier Series on [−π, π] & Piecewise Functions
notes.content: Expand periodic piecewise functions; exploit even/odd symmetry; common exam: |x|, sawtooth, square wave; compute coefficients quickly.
keyTakeaways: Use orthogonality of sines/cosines to get coefficients.
Gibbs phenomenon near jump discontinuities.
Half-range expansions reduce work.

notes.title: Beta & Gamma Functions (Improper Integrals)
notes.content: Euler's Γ generalizes factorial; Beta integral relates via B(m,n)=Γ(m)Γ(n)/Γ(m+n). Useful to evaluate definite integrals appearing in CSS.
keyTakeaways: Memorize Γ(n)=(n−1)! for n∈ℕ; Γ(1/2)=√π.
Common substitution tricks reduce integrals to Beta/Gamma.
Know relation B(x,y)=∫₀¹ t^{x−1}(1−t)^{y−1} dt.

notes.title: Plane Curves: Tangent/Normal, Arc Length & Curvature
notes.content: Compute tangents/normals; arc length via ∫√(1+(y′)²) dx; curvature κ formulas; CSS often asks for evolutes/pedal equations of classic curves.
keyTakeaways: Curvature κ = |dT/ds|; multiple equivalent formulas in x(t)/y(t) or y(x).
Parametric/polar conversions frequently save effort.
Know standard curves: cycloid, cardioid, astroid.

notes.title: Pedal Equations & Applications
notes.content: Pedal equation relates distance r from fixed point to point on curve and perpendicular p from point to tangent. Appears in some classic geometry questions.
keyTakeaways: Useful identities for conics (e.g., parabola at focus: p²=ar).
Know a few standard pedal forms to speed solutions.
Pairs with curvature/evolute questions.

notes.title: Conic Sections: Tangents/Normals & Standard Forms
notes.content: Ellipse/parabola/hyperbola properties; find tangent/normal; convert general quadratic to standard form; optical properties occasionally tested.
keyTakeaways: Memorize standard forms and focal parameters.
Implicit differentiation for tangent/normal lines.
Half-angle and parametric forms useful for speed.

notes.title: 3D Geometry: Planes, Lines, Quadric Surfaces & Distances
notes.content: Equations of planes/lines/spheres; quadric surfaces; shortest distance between skew lines; distance between parallel lines/planes.
keyTakeaways: Skew lines: distance via |(a₂−a₁)·(b₁×b₂)|/|b₁×b₂|.
Intercept form of planes and tangent planes to quadrics are frequent.
Draw quick diagram to avoid sign mistakes.

notes.title: Cayley–Hamilton in Computation (Inverse & Powers of A)
notes.content: Use characteristic polynomial to express A⁻¹ (when det≠0) and reduce high powers; common CSS trick: avoid long multiplication.
keyTakeaways: Write p(A)=0 and solve for desired power or inverse.
Especially handy for 2×2 and 3×3 matrices.
Combine with eigen-decomposition when diagonalizable.

notes.title: Fourier Series — Visual & Intuition Boosters
notes.content: Use visual resources to grasp coefficients and partial sums; strengthens speed in expansions for |x| and periodic piecewise functions.
keyTakeaways: Even/odd decomposition halves the work.
Partial sums approximate discontinuities with Gibbs overshoot.
Link to heat equation justifies series relevance.

notes.title: CSS Syllabus & Paper Structure (Pure Mathematics)
notes.content: Know the official breakdown: Section-A (Modern Algebra), Section-B (Geometry/Vector/Calculus), Section-C (Analysis/Complex/Fourier). Avoid over-preparing off-syllabus topics.
keyTakeaways: Align prep to FPSC syllabus; practice past formats.
20 MCQs note applies broadly; check latest FPSC notices.
Time management: pick questions across sections as required.

resources.title: CSS Aspirants — Pure Math Syllabus PDF

notes.title: Past Papers: Patterns & Practice (2000–2025)
notes.content: Consistent recurrence of: normal subgroups/quotients; rank–nullity; Cayley–Hamilton; conics & 3D geometry; CR & residues; Fourier series of |x| or piecewise f.
keyTakeaways: Practice from multiple years to cover variants of the same core ideas.
Replicate full solutions under time constraints.
Flag your weak clusters and rotate drills.

resources.title: CSS Aspirants — Pure Math Past Papers (2020/2021 PDF)

notes.title: Exam-Focused Complex Integrals (Unit Circle/Rational Forms)
notes.content: Common CSS trick: integrate rational functions over |z|=1 using residues at poles inside. Convert real integrals via symmetry or contour choice.
keyTakeaways: Factor denominator; identify interior poles and compute residues.
Parametrize unit circle z=e^{it} if residue path is overkill.
Watch orientation (counterclockwise positive).

notes.title: Fast Geometry Toolbox for CSS
notes.content: Keep a mini-sheet: lines/planes forms; distance formulas; conic standard forms; curvature formulas; triple product identity for skew-line distance.
keyTakeaways: Skew lines distance: d = |(a₂−a₁)·(b₁×b₂)| / |b₁×b₂|.
Parallel lines in plane: d = |c₂−c₁|/√(a²+b²).
Curvature quick forms and tangent/normal unit vectors.
